section.title: &name-icinga; with &name-idoutils; Quickstart
section.para: This guide is intended to provide you with simple instructions on how to install &name-icinga; from source (code) and have it monitoring your local machine within 30 minutes.
No advanced installation options are discussed here - just the basics that will work for most of the users who want to get started.

This guide will give you examples for currently three different Linux distributions: &name-fedora;, &name-ubuntu; and &name-opensuse;. Similar distributions may work as well. That should include &name-redhat;, &name-centos;, &name-debian; and &name-sles;.
Other distributions may inherit from these examples.

para.emphasis: If you are planning to use &name-icinga; without &name-idoutils; please read instead!

section.para: If you follow these instructions, here's what you'll end up with:

listitem.para: &name-icinga; and the plugins will be installed underneath &url-icinga-base;
&name-icinga; will be configured to monitor a few aspects of your local system (CPU load, disk usage, etc.)
The &name-icinga; classic web interface will be accessible at http://localhost/icinga/ or http://yourdomain.com/icinga
A database which is filled by &name-icinga; using &name-idoutils;

section.para: During portions of the installation you'll need to have root access to your machine.

Make sure you've installed the following packages on your system before continuing. &name-idoutils; use the libdbi and the libdbi-drivers for several databases. The development libraries are also required. The following examples will show how to install the &name-idoutils; with the libdbi using &name-mysql; or &name-postgres;.

para.emphasis: SSL- Encryption between idomod and ido2db

section.para: If you want to use SSL-encryption you'll need openssl and openssl-devel/libssl-dev (Ubuntu) to be installed !
If you want Oracle as RDBM you'll need to install ocilib instead of libdbi.

listitem.para: Oracle libraries and SDK (e.g. Instant Client)
If you install from package, make sure the libraries are within PATH. Otherwise you need to set the Oracle libs during Icinga IDOUtils install using e.g. --with-oracle-lib=/path/to/instantclient

section.para: Get it from &url-orclib; and point configure to your Oracle libraries and header files e.g. from the Oracle instant client:
You can install your packages by running the following commands (as root or sudo):
section.programlisting: #> yum install httpd gcc glibc glibc-common gd gd-devel #> yum install libjpeg libjpeg-devel libpng libpng-devel
#> yum install mysql mysql-server libdbi libdbi-devel libdbi-drivers libdbi-dbd-mysql
#> yum install postgresql postgresql-server libdbi libdbi-devel libdbi-drivers libdbi-dbd-pgsql
#> apt-get install apache2 build-essential libgd2-xpm-dev #> apt-get install libjpeg62 libjpeg62-dev libpng12 libpng12-dev

note.para: The numbers <62/12> might differ, depending on your distribution

section.programlisting: #> apt-get install mysql-server mysql-client libdbi0 libdbi0-dev libdbd-mysql
#> apt-get install postgresql libdbi0 libdbi0-dev libdbd-pgsql
section.para: Use yast to install the packages for the RDBMS you want to use, i.e. "mysql", "mysql-devel", "mysql-client" or "postgresql", "postgresql-devel", "postgresql-server". In OpenSuSE 11 (SLES 11) the name of the package was changed from "mysql-devel" to "libmysqlclient-devel". The devel packages might be placed on the SDK DVDs.

It is most likely that there aren't any libdbi packages so you have to download and compile the sources. Replace <rdbm> with your desired RDBM like mysql or pgsql. Remember that the Oracle driver is not yet working and read the appropriate section with ocilib instead of libdbi.

listitem.para: Download and extract the tar.gz files

para.programlisting: #> tar xvzf libdbi-0.8.3.tar.gz #> tar xvzf libdbi-drivers-0.8.3-1.tar.gz

listitem.para: Install libdbi. Maybe you have to specify additional options with configure (set --prefix=/usr ... )

section.para: Become the root user.
Create a new &name-icinga; user account and give it a password.
On some distributions you'll need to add the group in a single step:
For sending commands from the classic web interface to &name-icinga;, you'll need to create a new group icinga-cmd. Add the webuser and the &name-icinga;user to this group:
section.programlisting: #> /usr/sbin/groupadd icinga-cmd #> /usr/sbin/usermod -a -G icinga-cmd icinga #> /usr/sbin/usermod -a -G icinga-cmd www-data (or www, wwwrun, apache depending on the distribution)

note.para: Some usermod-versions (e.g in OpenSuSE 11 and SLES 11, resp.) are lacking the option -a. In this case please omit the option -a.

important.para: Solaris only supports groupnames with max. 8 characters, please use icingcmd instead of icinga-cmd.

section.para: Change to your local source directory i.e. /usr/src

Either fetch the actual icinga-core snapshot from &name-icinga; GIT #> git clone git://git.icinga.org/icinga-core.git #> git submodule init #> git submodule update or from the &name-icinga; Website . Don't forget to download the Nagios Plugins
Extract the &name-icinga; source code tarball (or change directory to the GIT snapshot)

note.para: This absolute path is meant when we refer to '/path/to/icinga-src/' in the following text.

section.para: Run the &name-icinga; configure script and enable &name-idoutils;. You will get help by using the --help flag:

important.para: Compiling on Solaris might fail upon unresolved library dependencies on gethostbyname. In that case run this before running configure:

section.para: #> ./configure --with-command-group=icinga-cmd --enable-idoutils --enable-oracle If you didn't install Oracle libraries to PATH, you can point configure there:
If you didn't install ocilib to the default path (/usr/local) you can point configure to the lib/inc directories:

note.para: If you want to change RDBM from Oracle to others, you need to recompile and reinstall &name-idoutils;!

section.para: Compile the &name-icinga; source code. There is also an extra option for &name-idoutils; (make idoutils) if you need to recompile only this module. To see available options, only use "make".

Install binaries, init script, sample config files and set permissions on the external command directory. Also install the &name-idoutils;. #> make install #> make install-init #> make install-config #> make install-commandmode #> make install-idoutils or shorter #> make fullinstall
The &name-icinga;-API will be installed during "make install" so if you are required to install it manually please try: #> make install-apiThis will be mandatory for Icinga-Web.
Don't start &name-icinga; yet - there's still more that needs to be done...
Sample configuration files have been installed by using make install-config into &url-icinga-base;/etc/. You'll need to make just one change before you proceed...

Edit the &url-icinga-base;/etc/objects/contacts.cfg config file with your favourite editor and change the email address associated with the icingaadmin contact definition to the address you'd like to use for receiving alerts.
section.programlisting: #> cd &url-icinga-base;/etc/ #> mv idomod.cfg-sample idomod.cfg #> mv ido2db.cfg-sample ido2db.cfg

section.para: Reload and configure database scheme.
Edit the DB config file to customize &name-idoutils;

Create a database schema and username/password (refer to the Oracle documentation at &url-oracle; or consult your DBA). Import the database scheme with sqlplus (or your preferred method). Copy module/idoutils/db/oracle/oracle.sql to $ORACLE_HOME
Edit the DB config file to customize IDOUtils. Remember that Oracle ignores the db host, instead point db_name to //DBSERVER/DBNAME
&name-icinga; ships with the classic web interface ("the CGIs") which can be installed via
section.programlisting: #> make cgis #> make install-cgis #> make install-html
section.para: If you are interested in the new &name-icinga; Web, please refer to Install &name-icinga; Web Interface.
Install the &name-icinga; classic web config file in the Apache conf.d directory.
Create an icingaadmin account for logging into the &name-icinga; classic web interface. Remember the password you assign to this account - you'll need it later.
To change the password of an existing user or to add a new user, take this command:

para.emphasis: Compile and Install the Nagios Plugins

section.para: Extract the Nagios plugins source code tarball.
Compile and install the plugins by changing install directory to &url-icinga-base;

&name-rhel; and derived distributions like &name-fedora; and &name-centos; are shipped with activated SE&name-linux; (Security Enhanced &name-linux;) running in "enforcing" mode. This may lead to "Internal Server Error" messages when you try to invoke the &name-icinga;-CGIs.
Check if SE&name-linux; runs in enforcing mode
Set SE&name-linux; in "permissive" mode
To make this change permanent you have to adjust this setting in /etc/selinux/config and restart the system.

&name-idoutils; must be started and running before &name-icinga; is started.
Verify the sample &name-icinga; configuration files.
If there are no errors, start &name-icinga;.
Add &name-icinga; to the list of system services and have it automatically start when the system boots (make sure you have installed the init script before).

para.emphasis: Login to the Classic Web Interface

section.para: You should now be able to access the &name-icinga; classic web interface at the URL below. You'll be prompted for the username ( icingaadmin ) and password you specified earlier. http://localhost/icinga/ or http://yourdomain.com/icinga/

Click on the "Service Detail" navbar link to see details of what's being monitored on your local machine. It will take a few minutes for &name-icinga; to check all the services associated with your machine.
Make sure your system's firewall rules are configured to allow access to the web server if you want to access the &name-icinga; classic interface remotely.

Setting up your mail transfer agent (MTA) like exim, sendmail or postfix to allow &name-icinga; sending notification emails won't be explained here. Please refer to the &name-nagioswiki; for more resources.
There are several tweaks for the &name-idoutils; (former NDOUtils of &name-nagios;) available.

Congratulations! You successfully installed &name-icinga; with &name-idoutils;. Your journey into monitoring has just begun. You'll no doubt want to monitor more than just your local machine, so check out the chapter on "Getting Started" about "Monitoring ..."
